idCitation.collTitle: NOAA Fisheries, Northwest Fisheries Science Center, GIS Data Layers for 2012 Review of West Coast Groundfish Essential Fish Habitat
idCitation.resTitle: Spatial Extent of Commercial Fixed Gear Fishing off the U.S. West Coast (1 Jan 2002 – 11 Jun 2006)

dataIdInfo.idPurp: The main purpose of this data layer is to help inform a periodic review of groundfish essential fish habitat (EFH) off the U.S. West Coast by the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) and the Pacific Fisheries Management Council (PFMC). The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act (MSA)(16 USC 1801 et seq) defines EFH as “those waters and substrate necessary to fish for spawning, breeding, feeding, or growth to maturity,” and requires Fishery Management Councils (FMCs) to describe and identify EFH in fishery management plans (FMPs). The FMPs should identify EFH based on current distribution, habitat components, historical presence, or other factors; and should also identify habitat requirements at each life stage and research needs. FMPs must evaluate potential adverse impacts from both fishing and non-fishing activities, as well as minimize adverse effects of fishing to the extent practicable. FMPs should also identify habitat areas of particular concern (HAPC) within EFH based on the habitat’s ecological function, sensitivity to human-induced disturbance, rarity, or whether development activities may stress a particular habitat.
dataIdInfo.idCredit: NOAA Fisheries (NMFS), Northwest Fisheries Science Center (NWFSC), Fishery Resource Analysis and Monitoring Division (FRAM), West Coast Groundfish Observer Program (WCGOP)

idPoC.rpOrgName: NOAA Fisheries, Northwest Fisheries Science Center, Fishery Resource Analysis and Monitoring Division

dataIdInfo.envirDesc: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; ESRI ArcGIS 10.0.4.4000
dataIdInfo.idAbs:
This data layer depicts the spatial extent of commercial fixed gear fishing off the U.S. West Coast from 1 Jan 2002 –11 Jun 2006. Records of fixed gear fishing locations were compiled from one source: observer records from the West Coast Groundfish Observer Program (WCGOP) database. The WCGOP database includes records of trips for vessels participating in the following sectors: limited entry sablefish-endorsed primary season, limited entry non-sablefish endorsed, open access fixed gear, Oregon and California nearshore. Annual WCGOP coverage of fixed gear sectors can be found online at: http://www.nwfsc.noaa.gov/research/divisions/fram/observer/sector_products.cfm. Since all fishing operations are not observed, neither the maps nor the data can be used to characterize the fishery completely. We urge caution when utilizing these data due to the complexity of groundfish management and fleet harvest dynamics.

Since fishing does not occur continuously between set and haul points for fixed gears, this data product is based on spatial locations of both set and haul coordinates (referred to as "fishing locations"). The extent polygon was created using an algorithm known as a convex hull. Convex hulls are a type of minimum bounding polygon that forms an “envelope” around a group of points, in this case, those representing fishing locations. The algorithm can be applied at various spatial scales. In this case, points were grouped into 0.5° latitude x 0.5° longitude blocks. The algorithm was then applied to each set of points within each block. Finally, all convex hull polygons were merged together. The resulting polygon encloses all points within the time period. The best way to interpret this data product is that no fixed gear fishing occurred outside of the extent polygon within the time period. In order to ensure confidentiality of vessel owners, each extent polygon encompasses fishing locations from at least three vessels. The result is an overestimation of the areas of seafloor actually contacted by the fishing gear. In fact, there are many areas within the extent polygon where no fishing occurred; hence this product is only intended to represent the gross“footprint”of fishing.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.
